article: Twenty years ago I drove a taxi for a living. One night I went to pick up a passenger at 2:30 AM. When I _ -,I found the building was dark except for a single light in a ground floor _ I walked to the door and knocked "Just a minute" answered a weak elderly _ After a long pause the door opened. A small woman in her eighties stood _ me by her side was a small suitcase. I took the suitcase to the car and then _ to help the woman. She took my arm and we walked _ toward the car. She kept thanking me for my kindness. "It's nothing" I told her. "I just try to _ my passengers the way I would want my mother treated." "Oh you're such a good man." She said. When we got into the taxi she gave me an address and then asked"Could you drive _ downtown" "It's not the shortest way" I answered quickly. "Oh I'm in no hurry " she said. "I'm on my way to a hospice. I don't have any _ left. The doctor says I don't have very long." I quietly reached over and shut off the meter. For the next two hours we drove through the city. She _ me the building where she had once worked the neighborhood where she had lived and the furniture shop that had once been a ballroom where she had gone _ as a girl. Sometimes she'd ask me to slow down in front of a _ building and would sit staring into the darkness saying nothing. At _ she suddenly said" I'm tired. Let's go now." We drove in silence to the _ she had given me. "How much do I _ you" she asked. "Nothing." I said. "You have to make a living" she answered. "Oh there are other _ " I answered. Almost without thinking I _ and gave her a hug. She held onto me tightly. Our hug ended with her remark"You gave an old woman a little moment of joy." I walked into the _ morning light. Behind me, a door shut. It was the sound of the closing of a life.
